columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the salvage value of the asset using the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) method of solving for the depreciation.

At the end of the lifespan of an asset or at the end of the project, the salvage value of assets are solved. The salvage value is the value of an asset after depreciation is complete at the end of its lifespan. 

In order to solve for this, we will use the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) method of solving for the depreciation. MACRS is used since it considers the "age" of the asset.

For this particular asset, we will use the following depreciation rates based on MACRS:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.20\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.32\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.192\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1152\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.1152\\
\text{Year 6}&=0.0576
\end{aligned}$$

To solve this problem, we will multiply the initial value of the asset by the depreciation rate in Year 1. After which, the depreciation will be subtracted from the initial value to get the book value at Year 1. 

The process will repeat but the depreciation will be subtracted from the preceding book value.

Solving for the depreciation at **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,020,000
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 1 is $\$1,020,000$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the book value at Year 1:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value}&=\$5,100,000-\$1,020,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,080,000
\end{aligned}$$

The book value at the end of Year 1 is $\$4,080,000$

Solving for the depreciation at **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.32\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,632,000
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 2 is $\$1,632,000$

Subtract the depreciation from book value of Year 1 to get the book value at Year 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value}&=\$4,080,000-\$1,632,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,448,000
\end{aligned}$$

The book value at the end of Year 2 is $\$2,448,000$

Solving for the depreciation at **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.192\\[15 pt]
&=\$979,200
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 3 is $\$979,200$

Subtract the depreciation from book value of Year 2 to get the book value at Year 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value}&=\$2,448,000-\$979,200\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,468,800
\end{aligned}$$

The book value at the end of Year 3 is $\$1,468,800$

Solving for the depreciation at **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.1152\\[15 pt]
&=\$587,520
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 4 is $\$587,520$

Subtract the depreciation from book value of Year 3 to get the book value at Year 4:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value}&=\$1,468,800-\$587,520\\[15 pt]
&=\$881,280
\end{aligned}$$

The book value at the end of Year 4 is $\$881,280$.
Since we are selling the asset after Year 4, we will no longer get the depreciation and book value for the next years.

Now that we have this value, we will then get the difference between the book value and the salvage value.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,600,000-\$881,280&=\$718,720
\end{aligned}$$

This means that we are selling the asset $\$718,720$ more than the expected value.

Since there is a difference between the book value and the sale value, then there will be a tax burden. This can be solved by multiplying the value in Step 14 by the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax burden}&=\$718,720 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$150,931.20
\end{aligned}$$

This means that $\$150,931.20$ will be subtracted from the salvage value as tax.

Solving for the aftertax salvage value, we can simply subtract the tax burden from the salvage value.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Aftertax salvage value}&=\$1,600,000-\$150,931.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,449,068.80
\end{aligned}$$

This means that after taxes, the asset will be sold at $\$1,449,068.80$
